awd_titl_txt: TRIPODS+X:RES:Collaborative Research: Learning with Expert-In-The-Loop for Multimodal Weakly Labeled Data and an Application to Massive Scale Medical Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
The methods developed in this project address pressing problems at the interface of machine learning and a life-sciences application. This work hopes to spur a rich variety of followup research that not only builds on the mathematical tools developed but also on the insights gained from the project's focus on interpretable and interactive machine learning. As a key application, implementation of the technology obtained from this research on medical images will enable automatic report generation. This technology could reduce the workload of radiologists significantly, and hence reduce human error and optimize resource utilization. Ultimately, reduction in human error or missing cases in radiology can greatly benefit patient well-being and care. More broadly, the work will enhance the ongoing adoption of data-driven thinking in healthcare and thereby help accelerate new discoveries. This project also impacts education, and involves intellectual and professional development of students at a variety of academic stages. 

Most applications of machine learning to medical imaging (and other human-centric tasks) focus on supervised learning, which demands a large amount of expensive labeled-data. This limitation recurs throughout applications, while real-world use of machine learning demands robustness as well as an ability to work with limited supervision. This project focuses on developing new machine learning tools for working with weak-supervision, while advancing state-of-the-art in interpretable and interactive learning. Moreover, attention to large-scale data and incorporation of domain knowledge is paid, whenever feasible. The project shall also apply the theoretical advances that it will make to a real-world medical imaging application. Theoretical advances of the proposed work will rely on tools from geometry, especially metric learning (including over infinite dimensional spaces), mathematical models motivated by optimal transport theory, as well as nonlinear representations based on neural networks as well as kernel methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The project focused on the development and improvement of machine learning models and techniques, with a particular emphasis on human-in-the-loop systems, explainability, incorporating domain knowledge, and data-efficient learning. The project resulted in 21 publications in top conference and journal venues, highlighting the significant progress made in these areas. In the area of explainability, we developed a Counterfactual Explainer to address the "why" question in model explainability and a method using ideas from causal inference to open up a black box classifier and identify internal neurons that could be understood by humans. These methods were extensively evaluated through human studies and were shown to be effective in calibrating the overconfidence of a classifier. In the area of incorporating domain knowledge, we developed a principled approach that allows external information to be incorporated into the posterior estimation of a generic graphical model, as well as a method for accounting for expert-curated similarity when extracting feature embeddings for small molecules. In the area of data-efficient learning, we developed a range of methods for using weakly supervised and noisy labels, improving domain generalization and adaptation, and self-supervised and unsupervised learning. These methods were applied to a variety of tasks, including image segmentation, style transfer, and volumetric medical image generation.

Broader Impact: The work from this project has the potential to have a wide range of practical impacts, particularly in fields where explainability and trust in machine learning models is of critical importance. For example, in healthcare, the ability to clearly understand and trust the decisions made by machine learning models can be crucial for improving patient outcomes. The methods developed for incorporating domain knowledge and data-efficient learning could also have significant impacts in a variety of fields by allowing for more accurate and reliable predictions with limited amounts of data. Additionally, the project's focus on human-in-the-loop systems emphasizes the importance of ensuring that machine learning models are developed in a way that is transparent and understandable to humans, which could have broader societal implications for the responsible development and deployment of these technologies.
